factoid: Count Rostóv took Natásha to visit Prince Nicholas Bolkónski.
Márya Dmítrievna advised Count Rostóv to take Natásha to visit Prince Nicholas Bolkónski.
Count Rostóv was afraid during the visit.
Count Rostóv remembered his last interview with Prince Nicholas Bolkónski at the time of enrollment.
During that interview, Prince Nicholas Bolkónski angrily reprimanded Count Rostóv for not providing his full quota of men.
Natásha wore her best gown.
Natásha was in high spirits.
Natásha thought that people cannot help liking her.
Natásha believed that everybody has always liked her.
Natásha is willing to do anything people wish.
Natásha is ready to be fond of Prince Nicholas Bolkónski because he is her father.
Natásha is ready to be fond of Princess Mary because she is her sister.
Natásha believes there is no reason for people not to like her.
Count Rostóv and Natásha drove up to the gloomy old house on the Vozdvízhenka.
Count Rostóv and Natásha entered the vestibule.
Count Rostóv said “Well, the Lord have mercy on us!” half in jest, half in earnest.
Natásha noticed that Count Rostóv was flurried when entering the anteroom.
Natásha timidly and softly inquired whether Prince Nicholas Bolkónski and Princess Mary were at home.
When Count Rostóv and Natásha were announced, the servants showed perturbation.
The footman who had gone to announce Count Rostóv and Natásha was stopped by another footman in the large hall.
The two footmen whispered to one another.
A maidservant ran into the hall and hurriedly mentioned Princess Mary.
An old, cross-looking footman announced to Count Rostóv and Natásha that Prince Nicholas Bolkónski was not receiving them, but Princess Mary begged them to walk up.
Mademoiselle Bourienne was the first person to meet Count Rostóv and Natásha.
Mademoiselle Bourienne greeted Count Rostóv and Natásha with special politeness.
Mademoiselle Bourienne showed Count Rostóv and Natásha to Princess Mary's room.
Princess Mary looked excited and nervous.
Princess Mary's face flushed in patches.
Princess Mary ran in to meet Count Rostóv and Natásha.
Princess Mary treaded heavily.
Princess Mary tried vainly to appear cordial and at ease.
Princess Mary did not like Natásha at first glance.
Princess Mary thought Natásha was too fashionably dressed.
Princess Mary thought Natásha was frivolously gay.
Princess Mary thought Natásha was vain.
Princess Mary was prejudiced against Natásha by involuntary envy of Natásha's beauty, youth, and happiness.
Princess Mary was prejudiced against Natásha by jealousy of her brother's love for Natásha.
Princess Mary was agitated because Count Rostóv and Natásha were announced.
Prince Nicholas Bolkónski shouted that he did not wish to see Count Rostóv and Natásha.
Prince Nicholas Bolkónski said Princess Mary might see them if she chose.
Prince Nicholas Bolkónski said Count Rostóv and Natásha were not to be admitted to him.
Princess Mary had decided to receive Count Rostóv and Natásha.
Princess Mary feared that Prince Nicholas Bolkónski might at any moment indulge in some freak.
Princess Mary feared Prince Nicholas Bolkónski seemed upset by Count Rostóv's visit.
Count Rostóv said “There, my dear princess, I’ve brought you my song.”
Count Rostóv bowed and looked round uneasily as if afraid that Prince Nicholas Bolkónski might appear.
Count Rostóv said he was glad that Count Rostóv and Princess Mary would get to know one another.
Count Rostóv said the prince was still ailing.
Count Rostóv rose after a few more remarks.
Count Rostóv asked Princess Mary to allow him to leave Natásha in her hands for a quarter of an hour.
Count Rostóv said he would drive around to see Anna Semënovna.
Count Rostóv said Anna Semënovna was near in the Dogs' Square.
Count Rostóv said he would come back for Natásha.
Count Rostóv devised the diplomatic ruse to give Natásha and Princess Mary an opportunity to talk freely.
Count Rostóv devised the diplomatic ruse to avoid the danger of encountering Prince Nicholas Bolkónski.
Count Rostóv was afraid of Prince Nicholas Bolkónski.
Count Rostóv did not mention the ruse to Natásha.
Natásha noticed Count Rostóv's nervousness and anxiety.
Natásha felt mortified by Count Rostóv's nervousness.
Natásha blushed for Count Rostóv.
Natásha grew angrier at having blushed.
Natásha looked at Princess Mary with a bold and defiant expression.
Natásha's expression indicated she was not afraid of anybody.
Princess Mary told Count Rostóv that she would be delighted.
Princess Mary begged Count Rostóv to stay longer at Anna Semënovna's.
Count Rostóv departed.
